text:
The **gross domestic product (GDP) of Niger** was $16.617 billion US dollars
in 2023, according to official data from the World Bank. This data is based
largely on internal markets, subsistence agriculture, and the export of raw
commodities: foodstuffs to neighbors and raw minerals to world markets. Niger,
a landlocked West African nation that straddles the Sahel, has consistently
been ranked on the bottom of the Human Development Index, at 0.394 as of 2019.
It has a very low per capita income, and ranks among the least developed and
most heavily indebted countries in the world, despite having large raw
commodities and a relatively stable government and society not currently
affected by civil war or terrorism. Economic activity centers on subsistence
agriculture, animal husbandry, re-export trade, and export of uranium.

The 50% devaluation of the West African CFA franc in January 1994 boosted
exports of livestock, cowpeas, onions, and the products of Niger's small
cotton industry. Exports of cattle to neighboring Nigeria, as well as
groundnuts and oil remain the primary non-mineral exports. The government
relies on bilateral and multilateral aid – which was suspended briefly
following coups in 1996 and 1999 – for operating expenses and public
investment. Short-term prospects depend on continued World Bank and IMF debt
relief and extended aid. The post-1999 government has broadly adhered to
privatization and market deregulation plans instituted by these funders. Niger
is a least developed country according to the United Nations.
openai_summarised_points: • The gross domestic product (GDP) of Niger was $16.617 billion US dollars in 2023, based on official data from the World Bank.
• Niger’s economy relies heavily on internal markets, subsistence agriculture, and the export of raw commodities, including foodstuffs to neighboring countries and raw minerals to global markets.
• Niger is a landlocked West African nation located in the Sahel region.
• As of 2019, Niger was ranked at the bottom of the Human Development Index with a value of 0.394.
• The country has a very low per capita income and is classified among the least developed and most heavily indebted countries worldwide.
• Despite its economic challenges, Niger possesses large raw commodity reserves and maintains a relatively stable government and society, currently free from civil war or terrorism.
• The main economic activities in Niger include subsistence agriculture, animal husbandry, re-export trade, and uranium exportation.
• In January 1994, the West African CFA franc was devalued by 50%, which boosted exports of livestock, cowpeas, onions, and products from Niger’s small cotton industry.
• Primary non-mineral exports from Niger include cattle (especially to neighboring Nigeria), groundnuts, and oil.
• The Nigerien government depends on bilateral and multilateral aid for operating expenses and public investment; this aid was briefly suspended following military coups in 1996 and 1999.
• Niger’s short-term economic prospects rely on continued debt relief from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF), as well as extended foreign aid.
• Since 1999, the government has generally complied with privatization and market deregulation policies promoted by international financial institutions such as the World Bank and IMF.
• The United Nations classifies Niger as a least developed country.

Economic map of Niger (1969). Peanut cultivation areas in purple, Rice in
green, The remainder of agricultural land in orange. The northern limits of
seasonal livestock forage is in brown.

Niger's economy is based largely on subsistence crops, livestock, and some of
the world's largest uranium deposits. Drought cycles, desertification, a 3.4%
population growth rate and the drop in world demand for uranium have undercut
an already marginal economy. Traditional subsistence farming, herding, small
trading, and informal markets dominate an economy that generates few formal
sector jobs. Between 1988 and 1995 28% to 30% of the total economy of Niger
was in the unregulated informal sector, including small and even large scale
rural and urban production, transport and services.
openai_summarised_points: • The economic map of Niger from 1969 indicates peanut cultivation areas in purple, rice cultivation areas in green, and the remainder of agricultural land in orange, with the northern limits of seasonal livestock forage marked in brown.
• Niger's economy is predominantly based on subsistence crops, livestock rearing, and exploitation of some of the world's largest uranium deposits.
• The economy faces significant challenges including recurring drought cycles, ongoing desertification, a high population growth rate of 3.4%, and a decline in global demand for uranium.
• These factors have severely weakened an already marginal economy, limiting economic growth and development.
• The economic structure is largely traditional, with subsistence farming, herding, small-scale trading, and informal markets serving as the main economic activities.
• The formal sector in Niger generates very few jobs, reflecting the dominance of informal economic activities.

• Between 1988 and 1995, the unregulated informal sector accounted for approximately 28% to 30% of Niger’s total economy, encompassing a wide range of activities including small and large-scale rural and urban production, transportation, and services.

text:
The GDP per capita of Niger grew 10% in the 1960s. However, this proved
unsustainable and it consequently shrank by 27% in the 1980s and a further 48%
in the 1990s. Much of this GDP is explained through the exploitation of
uranium at Arlit in the far north of the country. Ore is partially processed
on site by foreign mining corporations and transported by truck to Benin.
Fluctuation of GDP can be mapped to changes in international uranium prices,
as well as price negotiations with the main mining company, France's Orano
Cycle. Price rises in the mid-1970s were followed by a collapse in the market
price through much of the 1980s and 1990s. Thus the country's GDP per capita
has little direct impact on the average Nigerien, although uranium funds much
government operation. The 2006 Human Development Index ranked Niger sixth from
worst in the world, with a HDI of 0.370: 174 of 179 nations.
openai_summarised_points: • The GDP per capita of Niger experienced a growth of 10% during the 1960s, indicating an initial period of economic expansion.
• This growth was unsustainable, leading to a significant contraction of GDP per capita by 27% in the 1980s.
• The decline continued into the 1990s, with a further shrinkage of 48% in GDP per capita during that decade.
• A substantial portion of Niger's GDP is derived from the exploitation of uranium deposits located in Arlit, a region in the far north of the country.
• Uranium ore extracted in Arlit is partially processed on-site by foreign mining corporations before being transported by truck to Benin for further handling.
• Fluctuations in Niger’s GDP per capita closely correlate with changes in international uranium prices, reflecting the country’s economic dependence on this commodity.
• Price negotiations with France's Orano Cycle, the main mining company operating in Niger, also significantly influence the country’s uranium revenue and thus GDP.
• The mid-1970s saw a rise in uranium prices, which temporarily boosted Niger’s GDP per capita.
• This was followed by a collapse in uranium market prices throughout much of the 1980s and 1990s, contributing to the decline in GDP per capita during these decades.
• Despite uranium mining funding much of the government’s operations, the fluctuations in GDP per capita have minimal direct impact on the average Nigerien citizen’s economic well-being.
• According to the 2006 Human Development Index (HDI), Niger was ranked sixth from the bottom globally, with an HDI score of 0.370, placing it 174th out of 179 nations assessed.

Niger's exports in 2006

Of Niger's exports, foreign exchange earnings from livestock, although
impossible to quantify, are second only to those from uranium. Actual exports
far exceed official statistics, which often fail to detect large herds of
animals informally crossing into Nigeria. Some hides and skins are exported
and some are transformed into handicrafts.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2006, Niger's foreign exchange earnings from livestock exports were the second largest after uranium, although the exact value was impossible to quantify.
• Official export statistics significantly underestimated livestock exports due to the informal cross-border movement of large herds into Nigeria.
• In addition to live animals, some hides and skins were exported from Niger during this period.
• A portion of these hides and skins was further processed domestically into handicrafts before export.

text:
The persistent uranium price slump has brought lower revenues for Niger's
uranium sector. Uranium no longer provides the majority of national export
proceeds. The nation enjoyed substantial export earnings and rapid economic
growth during the 1960s and 1970s after the opening of two large uranium mines
near the northern town of Arlit. When the uranium-led boom ended in the early
1980s, however, the economy stagnated and new investment since then has been
limited. Niger's two uranium mines (SOMAIR's open pit mine and COMINAK's
underground mine) are owned by a French-led consortium and operated by French
interests.

The open pit COMINAK uranium mine at Arlit.

Exploitable deposits of gold are known to exist in Niger in the region between
the Niger River and the border with Burkina Faso. Substantial deposits of
phosphates, coal, iron, limestone, and gypsum have also been found. Numerous
foreign companies, including American firms, have taken out exploration
licenses for concessions in the gold seam in western Niger, which also
contains deposits of other minerals.

Several oil companies explored for petroleum since 1992 in the Djado plateau
in north-eastern Niger and the Agadem basin, north of Lake Chad but made no
discoveries worth developing at the time. In June 2007, however, China
National Petroleum Corporation (state-owned by the People's Republic of China)
signed a US$5 billion agreement to extract oil in the Agadem block, as well as
build a 20,000 barrels (3,200 m3) per day oil refinery and a 2,000 km oil
pipeline in the country; production is expected to start in 2009.

Niger's known coal reserves, with low energy and high ash content, cannot
compete against higher quality coal on the world market. However, the
parastatal SONICHAR (Société nigérienne de charbon) in Tchirozerine (north of
Agadez) extracts coal from an open pit and fuels an electricity generating
plant that supplies energy to the uranium mines.

A test Oil well in the Tenere Desert, January 2008.
openai_summarised_points: • The persistent slump in uranium prices has resulted in lower revenues for Niger's uranium sector, causing uranium to no longer constitute the majority of the nation's export proceeds.
• Niger experienced substantial export earnings and rapid economic growth during the 1960s and 1970s following the opening of two large uranium mines near the northern town of Arlit.
• The uranium-led economic boom ended in the early 1980s, leading to economic stagnation and limited new investment in the sector thereafter.
• Niger’s two uranium mines consist of SOMAIR’s open pit mine and COMINAK’s underground mine, both owned by a French-led consortium and operated by French interests.
• Exploitable gold deposits are known to exist in Niger in the region between the Niger River and the border with Burkina Faso.
• Substantial deposits of phosphates, coal, iron, limestone, and gypsum have also been identified within Niger.
• Numerous foreign companies, including American firms, have obtained exploration licenses for concessions in the western Niger gold seam, which also contains deposits of other minerals.

• Since 1992, several oil companies have explored for petroleum in the Djado plateau in northeastern Niger and the Agadem basin north of Lake Chad, but initially made no commercially viable discoveries.
• In June 2007, the China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), a state-owned enterprise of the People's Republic of China, signed a US$5 billion agreement to extract oil in the Agadem block.
• The CNPC agreement also includes plans to build a 20,000 barrels per day (3,200 m³/day) oil refinery and a 2,000 km oil pipeline within Niger, with production expected to commence in 2009.
• Niger’s known coal reserves have low energy content and high ash content, making them noncompetitive against higher quality coal on the global market.

• The parastatal company SONICHAR (Société nigérienne de charbon), located in Tchirozerine north of Agadez, extracts coal from an open pit mine and supplies fuel to an electricity generating plant that powers the uranium mines.
• A test oil well was drilled in the Tenere Desert in January 2008 as part of ongoing petroleum exploration efforts.

After the economic competitiveness created by the January 1994 CFA franc
devaluation contributed to an annual average economic growth of 3.5%
throughout the mid-1990s, the economy stagnated due to the sharp reduction in
foreign aid in 1999, which gradually resumed in 2000, and poor rains in 2000.
Reflecting the importance of the agricultural sector, the return of good rains
was the primary factor underlying a projected growth of 4.5% for 2001.
openai_summarised_points: • The January 1994 devaluation of the CFA franc enhanced Niger's economic competitiveness, leading to an annual average economic growth rate of 3.5% throughout the mid-1990s.
• In 1999, Niger's economy experienced stagnation primarily due to a sharp reduction in foreign aid.
• Foreign aid to Niger gradually resumed in 2000, but economic recovery was hindered by poor rainfall during the same year.

• The agricultural sector played a critical role in Niger's economy, with the return of favorable rainfall conditions being the main factor driving a projected economic growth rate of 4.5% for the year 2001.

text:
In recent years, the Government of Niger promulgated revisions to the
investment code (1997 and 2000), petroleum code (1992), and mining code
(1993), all with attractive terms for investors. The present government
actively seeks foreign private investment and considers it key to restoring
economic growth and development. With the assistance of the United Nations
Development Programme (UNDP), it has undertaken a concerted effort to
revitalize the sector.
openai_summarised_points: • In recent years, the Government of Niger has promulgated revisions to several key legislative frameworks governing investment, including the investment code (originally enacted in 1997 and revised in 2000), the petroleum code (established in 1992), and the mining code (established in 1993), all of which contain attractive terms designed to encourage foreign investors.
• The current government of Niger actively seeks to attract foreign private investment, viewing it as a critical component for restoring the country's economic growth and development.
• To support this objective, the government has collaborated with the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in a concerted effort aimed at revitalizing the investment sector within Niger.

Niger shares a common currency, the CFA franc, and a common central bank, the
Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO), with six other members of the
West African Monetary Union. The Treasury of the Government of France
supplements the BCEAO's international reserves in order to maintain a fixed
rate of 100 CFA (Communauté Financière Africaine) to the French franc (to the
euro as of January 1, 2002).
openai_summarised_points: • Niger uses the CFA franc as its official currency, which it shares with six other member countries of the West African Monetary Union.
• The common central bank for Niger and the other member countries is the Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO).
• The Treasury of the Government of France supports the BCEAO by supplementing its international reserves.
• This financial support from France helps maintain a fixed exchange rate of 100 CFA francs to one French franc.
• Since January 1, 2002, the fixed exchange rate has been maintained at 100 CFA francs to one euro, following the euro's adoption.

text:
In January 2000, Niger's newly elected government inherited serious financial
and economic problems including a virtually empty treasury, past-due salaries
(11 months of arrears) and scholarship payments, increased debt, reduced
revenue performance, and lower public investment. In December 2000, Niger
qualified for enhanced debt relief under the International Monetary Fund
program for Highly Indebted Poor Countries and concluded an agreement with the
Fund on a Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF).

In addition to changes in the budgetary process and public finances, the new
government has pursued economic restructuring towards the IMF promoted
privatization model. This has included the privatization of water distribution
and telecommunications and the removal of price protections for petroleum
products, allowing prices to be set by world market prices. Further
privatizations of public enterprises are in the works. In its effort to comply
with the IMF's Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility plan, the government is
also taking action to reduce corruption and, as the result of a participatory
process encompassing civil society, has devised a Poverty Reduction Strategy
Plan that focuses on improving health, primary education, rural
infrastructure, and judicial restructuring.
openai_summarised_points: • In January 2000, Niger’s newly elected government inherited severe financial and economic challenges, including a nearly empty treasury, 11 months of unpaid salary arrears, outstanding scholarship payments, increased national debt, diminished revenue collection, and reduced levels of public investment.

• In December 2000, Niger qualified for enhanced debt relief under the International Monetary Fund’s (IMF) program for Highly Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) and subsequently concluded an agreement with the IMF on a Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF).
• The new government implemented changes in the budgetary process and public financial management as part of broader economic restructuring efforts aligned with the IMF’s privatization model.
• Economic restructuring measures included the privatization of key public utilities such as water distribution and telecommunications sectors.
• The government removed price controls on petroleum products, allowing prices to be determined by global market rates rather than domestic regulation.
• Additional privatizations of public enterprises were planned as part of ongoing economic reforms.
• To comply with the IMF’s Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility plan, the government initiated measures to reduce corruption within public institutions.

• Through a participatory process involving civil society stakeholders, Niger developed a Poverty Reduction Strategy Plan focused on key sectors including health improvement, enhancement of primary education, development of rural infrastructure, and judicial system restructuring.

The most important donors in Niger are France, the European Union, the World
Bank, the IMF and other United Nations agencies (UNDP, UNICEF, FAO, WFP, NGOs,
and UNFPA). Other principal donors include the United States, Belgium,
Germany, Switzerland, Canada, and Saudi Arabia. USAID does not have an office
in Niger, the United States contributes nearly $10 million each year to
Niger's development. The US is also a major partner in policy coordination in
such areas as food security and HIV/AIDS. The importance of external support
for Niger's development is demonstrated by the fact that some 45% of the
government's FY 2002 budget, including 80% of its capital budget, derives from
donor resources.

In 2005 the UN drew attention to the increased need for foreign aid given
severe problems with drought and locusts resulting in a famine endangering the
lives of around a million people.
openai_summarised_points: • The principal foreign aid donors to Niger include France, the European Union, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and various United Nations agencies such as the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF), Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), World Food Programme (WFP), numerous non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA).
• Additional significant donors to Niger are the United States, Belgium, Germany, Switzerland, Canada, and Saudi Arabia.

• Although the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) does not maintain an office in Niger, the United States contributes approximately $10 million annually toward Niger’s development initiatives.
• The United States also plays a key role in policy coordination with Niger in critical sectors such as food security and HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment.
• External aid is crucial to Niger’s development, as evidenced by donor resources accounting for about 45% of the government’s fiscal year 2002 budget, including 80% of the capital budget.

• In 2005, the United Nations highlighted an urgent increase in the need for foreign aid in Niger due to severe drought and locust infestations, which precipitated a famine threatening the lives of approximately one million people.

• From 1980 to 2000, Niger’s GDP in billion US$ PPP increased from 4.1 in 1980 to 8.8 in 2000, while GDP per capita in US$ PPP rose from 704.0 to 775.4 over the same period, reflecting modest economic growth with fluctuations.

• During 1980-2000, nominal GDP in billion US$ decreased from 3.5 in 1980 to 2.2 in 2000, and nominal GDP per capita declined from 609.4 US$ to 197.3 US$, indicating currency valuation and inflation effects.

• Real GDP growth rates between 1980 and 2000 varied significantly, with a high of 10.0% in 1998 and a low of -16.8% in 1984; several years experienced negative growth, notably 1981 (-0.2%), 1983 (-3.9%), 1984 (-16.8%), 1990 (-1.3%), and 2000 (-1.2%).

• Inflation rates fluctuated widely from 1980 to 2000, peaking at 35.5% in 1994 and falling below 5% in several years (e.g., 1983 at 1.6%, 1987 at -6.6%, 1997 at 2.9%), with some years showing deflation (negative inflation).
• Unemployment rates from 1991 to 2000 remained low and stable at approximately 1.4% to 1.5%, though the International Monetary Fund considers these figures unreliable.

• Government debt as a percentage of GDP was first reported in 1995 at 69.4%, fluctuated between 61.3% and 82.1% through 2000, peaking at 82.1% in 2000, indicating a high debt burden at the end of the period.

• From 2001 onward, Niger’s GDP in billion US$ PPP rose steadily from 9.6 in 2001 to an estimated 55.3 in 2026, with GDP per capita in US$ PPP increasing from 819.6 in 2001 to 1,830.5 projected in 2026, demonstrating sustained economic growth.

• Nominal GDP in billion US$ increased from 2.4 in 2001 to an estimated 26.8 in 2026, while nominal GDP per capita rose from 207.8 US$ to 888.5 US$ over the same period, reflecting improved economic conditions and currency valuation.

• Real GDP growth rates from 2001 to 2026 showed generally positive trends, with notable peaks of 12.8% in 2022, 11.1% in 2023, and 10.5% in 2012; growth slowed to 1.2% in 2020 likely due to external shocks but recovered thereafter.

• Inflation rates from 2001 to 2026 mostly remained below 5%, with some exceptions such as 11.3% in 2008 and 7.8% in 2005; inflation stabilized around 2.0% from 2022 through 2026, indicating controlled price levels.
• Unemployment rates from 2001 to 2020 were low, ranging from 0.3% to 3.1%, with data unavailable for 2021 onward; the World Bank provided these figures, though IMF considers them unreliable.
• Government debt as a percentage of GDP decreased significantly from 74.0% in 2001 to an estimated 38.7% in 2026, reflecting improved fiscal management and debt reduction efforts.
• Inflation rates below 5% are highlighted in green in the original data, indicating periods of relative price stability, particularly from the mid-1990s onward and consistently from 2004 to 2026.

• The data sources include the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for staff estimates from 2021 to 2026 and the World Bank for unemployment rates, though the IMF questions the reliability of unemployment statistics.

• The economic indicators table comprehensively covers GDP in both purchasing power parity (PPP) and nominal terms, GDP per capita, real GDP growth rates, inflation rates, unemployment rates, and government debt as a percentage of GDP for Niger from 1980 through 2026.

text:
Niamey, Niger's capital and economic hub.

The economy of Niger centers on subsistence crops, livestock, and some of the
world's largest uranium deposits. Drought cycles, desertification, a 2.9%
population growth rate, and the drop in world demand for uranium have undercut
the economy.

Niger shares a common currency, the CFA franc, and a common central bank, the
Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO), with seven other members of the
West African Monetary Union. Niger is also a member of the Organization for
the Harmonization of Business Law in Africa (OHADA).

In December 2000, Niger qualified for enhanced debt relief under the
International Monetary Fund program for Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC)
and concluded an agreement with the Fund for Poverty Reduction and Growth
Facility (PRGF). Debt relief provided under the enhanced HIPC initiative
significantly reduces Niger's annual debt service obligations, freeing funds
for expenditures on basic health care, primary education, HIV/AIDS prevention,
rural infrastructure, and other programs geared at poverty reduction.

In December 2005, it was announced that Niger had received 100% multilateral
debt relief from the IMF, which translates into the forgiveness of
approximately US$86 million in debts to the IMF, excluding the remaining
assistance under HIPC. Nearly half of the government's budget is derived from
foreign donor resources. Future growth may be sustained by exploitation of
oil, gold, coal, and other mineral resources. Uranium prices have recovered
somewhat in the last few years. A drought and locust infestation in 2005 led
to food shortages for as many as 2.5 million Nigeriens.
openai_summarised_points: • Niamey, the capital city of Niger, serves as the country's primary economic hub, centralizing major economic activities and administration.

• Niger's economy is predominantly based on subsistence agriculture, livestock rearing, and the exploitation of some of the world's largest uranium deposits, which are a significant natural resource for the country.
• The economic stability of Niger has been adversely affected by recurring drought cycles and desertification, which undermine agricultural productivity and living conditions.
• Niger experiences a high population growth rate of 2.9%, which places additional pressure on the country's limited economic resources and infrastructure.
• A decline in global demand for uranium has negatively impacted Niger's economy, given the country's reliance on uranium exports as a major source of revenue.

• Niger participates in the West African Monetary Union, sharing the CFA franc as a common currency and the Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) as a common central bank with seven other member countries.
• The country is a member of the Organization for the Harmonization of Business Law in Africa (OHADA), which aims to unify business laws across member states to facilitate trade and investment.

• In December 2000, Niger qualified for enhanced debt relief under the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) initiative, marking a significant step towards debt sustainability.
• Concurrently, Niger concluded an agreement with the IMF for the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF), designed to support economic reforms and poverty alleviation.

• The enhanced HIPC debt relief substantially reduced Niger's annual debt service obligations, thereby freeing financial resources for critical social expenditures including basic health care, primary education, HIV/AIDS prevention, rural infrastructure development, and other poverty reduction programs.

• In December 2005, Niger was granted 100% multilateral debt relief by the IMF, resulting in the forgiveness of approximately US$86 million in debts owed to the IMF, excluding ongoing assistance under the HIPC framework.
• Foreign donor resources constitute nearly half of the Nigerien government's budget, highlighting the country's dependence on international aid for fiscal stability and development financing.
• Prospects for future economic growth in Niger include the exploitation of additional natural resources such as oil, gold, coal, and other minerals, which may diversify and strengthen the economy.
• Uranium prices have experienced some recovery in recent years, potentially improving export revenues and economic conditions.

• In 2005, Niger faced severe food shortages affecting up to 2.5 million people, caused by a combination of drought and a locust infestation, underscoring the vulnerability of the country’s food security to environmental shocks.

text:
The fertile south of Niger near the Niger River. Map and growing season for
the Nigerien Rice crop. Chart shows Normalized Difference Vegetation Index
against Long Rains Dry Season (July – Feb), measuring normal years crop growth
in the major Rice producing areas of Niger.

The agricultural economy is based largely upon internal markets, subsistence
agriculture, and the export of raw commodities: foodstuffs and cattle to
neighbors. Foreign exchange earnings from livestock, although difficult to
quantify, are considered the second source of export revenue behind mining and
oil exports. Actual exports far exceed official statistics, which often fail
to detect large herds of animals informally crossing into Nigeria. Some hides
and skins are exported, and some are transformed into handicrafts.

Niger's agricultural and livestock sectors are the mainstay of all but 18% of
the population. 14% of Niger's GDP is generated by livestock production
(camels, goats, sheep and cattle), said to support 29% of the population. Thus
53% of the population is actively involved in crop production. The 15% of
Niger's land that is arable is found mainly along its southern border with
Nigeria.

Drought has turned farmland into useless soil. A farmer examines the soil in
drought-stricken Niger during the 2005 famine.

In these areas, Pearl millet, sorghum, and cassava are the principal rain-fed
subsistence crops. Irrigated rice for internal consumption is grown in parts
of the Niger River valley in the west. While expensive, it has, since the
devaluation of the CFA franc, sold for below the price of imported rice,
encouraging additional production. Cowpeas and onions are grown for commercial
export, as are small quantities of garlic, peppers, potatoes, and wheat. Oasis
farming in small patches of the north of the country produces onions, dates,
and some market vegetables for export.

But for the most part, rural residents engaged in crop tending are clustered
in the south centre and south west of the nation, in those areas (the Sahel)
which can expect to receive between 300 and 600 mm (12 and 24 in) of rainfall
annually. A small area in the southern tip of the nation, surrounding Gaya can
expect to receive 700 to 900 mm (28 to 35 in) or rainfall. Northern areas
which support crops, such as the southern portions of the Aïr Massif and the
Kaouar oasis, rely upon oases and a slight increase in rainfall due to
mountain effects. Large portions of the northwest and far east of the nation,
while within the Sahara desert, see just enough seasonal rainfall to support
semi-nomadic animal husbandry. The populations of these areas, mostly Tuareg,
Wodaabe – Fula, and Toubou, travel south (a process called transhumance) to
pasture and sell animals in the dry season, north into the Sahara in the brief
rainy season.

Rainfall varies and when it is insufficient, Niger has difficulty feeding its
population and must rely on grain purchases and food aid to meet food
requirements. Rains, as in much of the Sahel, have been marked by annual
variability. This has been especially true in the 20th century, with the most
severe drought on record beginning in the late 1960s and lasting, with one
break, well into the 1980s. The long-term effect of this, especially to
pastoralist populations, remains in the 21st century, with those communities
which rely upon cattle, sheep, and camels husbandry losing entire herds more
than once during this period. Recent rains remain variable. For instance, the
rains in 2000 were not good, while those in 2001 were plentiful and well
distributed.

Soils that have become degraded, for example by intensive cereal production,
cover 50 per cent of Niger's land. Laterite soils have a high clay content,
which means they have higher Cation Exchange Capacity and water-holding
capacity than sandy soils. If laterite soils become degraded, a hard crust can
form on the surface, which hinders water infiltration and the emergence of
seedlings. It is possible to rehabilitate such soils, using a system called
the Bioreclamation of Degraded Lands.

This involves using indigenous water-harvesting methods (such as planting pits
and trenches), applying animal and plant residues, and planting high-value
fruit trees and indigenous vegetable crops that are tolerant of drought
conditions. The International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid
Tropics (ICRISAT) has employed this system to rehabilitate degraded laterite
soils in Niger and increase smallholder farmers' incomes. Trials have
demonstrated that a 200 m2 (2,153 sq ft) plot can yield an income of around
US$100, which is what men traditionally earn from millet production per
hectare (10000m2). As women are often given degraded soils, using this
practice has helped to improve livelihoods for women in Niger.

The Kandadji Dam on the Niger River, whose construction started in August
2008, is expected to improve agricultural production in the Tillaberi
Department by providing water for the irrigation of 6,000 hectares initially
and of 45,000 hectares by 2034.
openai_summarised_points: • The fertile southern region of Niger near the Niger River is a major rice-producing area, with crop growth measured by the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index during the Long Rains Dry Season (July to February), indicating normal year crop growth patterns.
• Niger's agricultural economy primarily relies on internal markets, subsistence farming, and the export of raw commodities such as foodstuffs and cattle to neighboring countries.

• Livestock exports, though difficult to quantify due to informal cross-border movements especially into Nigeria, are considered the second-largest source of export revenue after mining and oil; some hides and skins are exported and also used in handicraft production.

• The agricultural and livestock sectors support the majority of Niger’s population, with only 18% not dependent on these sectors; livestock production (camels, goats, sheep, and cattle) generates 14% of GDP and supports 29% of the population, while 53% of the population is engaged in crop production.
• Approximately 15% of Niger’s land is arable, predominantly located along the southern border with Nigeria.
• Drought has severely degraded farmland, exemplified by the 2005 famine when farmers examined drought-stricken soil.

• Principal rain-fed subsistence crops in the arable southern areas include pearl millet, sorghum, and cassava; irrigated rice is cultivated in parts of the Niger River valley in the west for internal consumption.
• Since the devaluation of the CFA franc, locally produced irrigated rice has become cheaper than imported rice, encouraging increased domestic production.
• Commercially grown crops for export include cowpeas and onions, with smaller quantities of garlic, peppers, potatoes, and wheat also cultivated for export.
• Oasis farming in northern Niger produces onions, dates, and some market vegetables for export.

• Rural crop farmers are mainly concentrated in the south centre and south west of Niger, within the Sahel region receiving between 300 and 600 mm (12 to 24 inches) of annual rainfall; the southern tip near Gaya receives 700 to 900 mm (28 to 35 inches) of rainfall.
• Northern crop-supporting areas such as the southern Aïr Massif and Kaouar oasis depend on oases and increased rainfall due to mountain effects.
• Large parts of northwest and far east Niger, located within the Sahara Desert, receive minimal seasonal rainfall sufficient only for semi-nomadic animal husbandry.

• Populations in these arid regions, mainly Tuareg, Wodaabe-Fula, and Toubou ethnic groups, practice transhumance—seasonal migration southward to pasture and sell animals during the dry season, and northward into the Sahara during the brief rainy season.
• Niger’s food security is highly vulnerable to rainfall variability; insufficient rains necessitate grain imports and food aid to meet population needs.

• The Sahel region, including Niger, has experienced marked annual rainfall variability throughout the 20th century, with the most severe drought beginning in the late 1960s and persisting intermittently into the 1980s.
• The prolonged drought severely impacted pastoralist communities, causing repeated loss of entire herds of cattle, sheep, and camels, with lingering effects into the 21st century.
• Rainfall remains variable in recent years, exemplified by poor rains in 2000 and plentiful, well-distributed rains in 2001.

• Soil degradation affects approximately 50% of Niger’s land, often due to intensive cereal cultivation; laterite soils, which have high clay content and thus higher cation exchange and water-holding capacities, can develop a hard crust when degraded, impeding water infiltration and seedling emergence.

• Soil rehabilitation is possible through Bioreclamation of Degraded Lands, a system involving indigenous water-harvesting techniques (e.g., planting pits and trenches), application of animal and plant residues, and cultivation of drought-tolerant high-value fruit trees and indigenous vegetables.

• The International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics (ICRISAT) has implemented this bioreclamation system in Niger, successfully rehabilitating degraded laterite soils and increasing smallholder farmers’ incomes.

• Trials demonstrate that a 200 m² (2,153 sq ft) plot using bioreclamation can yield approximately US$100 in income, comparable to the income men traditionally earn from millet production per hectare (10,000 m²).
• Since women are often allocated degraded soils, the bioreclamation practice has notably improved livelihoods for women in Niger.

• Construction of the Kandadji Dam on the Niger River began in August 2008; the dam is projected to enhance agricultural productivity in the Tillaberi Department by initially irrigating 6,000 hectares and expanding to 45,000 hectares by 2034.

As one of the Sahelian nations in West Africa, Niger has faced several
droughts which led to food shortages and, in some cases, famines since its
independence in 1963. This includes a series of droughts in the 1970s and
1980s and more recently in 2005–2006 and again in 2010. The existence of
widespread famine in 2005–2006 was debated by the government of Niger as well
some local NGOs.
openai_summarised_points: • Niger, as a Sahelian nation in West Africa, has experienced multiple droughts since its independence in 1963, which have caused food shortages and, in some instances, famines.
• Significant drought events occurred during the 1970s and 1980s, severely impacting agricultural productivity and food security in Niger.
• More recent droughts took place in the periods 2005–2006 and again in 2010, continuing the pattern of climate-induced food crises in the country.

• The existence of widespread famine during the 2005–2006 drought was a subject of debate, with the government of Niger and some local non-governmental organizations (NGOs) questioning the extent and severity of the famine conditions.

text:
The Niger mining industry is the main source of national exports, of which
uranium is the largest export. Niger has been a uranium exporter since the
1960s and has had substantial export earnings and rapid economic growth during
the 1960s and 1970s. The persistent uranium price slump has brought lower
revenues for Niger's uranium sector, although it still provides 72% of
national export proceeds. When the uranium-led boom ended in the early 1980s
the economy stagnated, and new investment since then has been limited. Niger's
two uranium mines—SOMAIR's open pit mine and COMINAK's underground mine—are
owned by a French-led consortium and operated by French company Orano.

As of 2007[update], many licences have been sold to other companies from
countries such as India, China, Canada and Australia in order to exploit new
deposits. In 2013, the government of Niger sought to increase its uranium
revenue by subjecting the two mining companies to a 2006 Mining Law. The
government argued that the application of the new law will balance an
otherwise unfavorable partnership between the government and Areva. The
company resisted the application of the new law that it feared would
jeopardize the financial health of the companies, citing declining market
uranium prices and unfavorable market conditions. In 2014, following nearly a
year long negotiation with the government of Niger, Areva agreed to the
application of 2006 Mining Law of Niger, which would increase the government's
uranium revenues from 5 to 12%.[_needs update_]

A farmer collecting millet in Koremairwa village in the Dosso department.

In addition to uranium, exploitable deposits of gold are known to exist in
Niger in the region between the Niger River and the border with Burkina Faso.
In 2004, the first Nigerien gold ingot was produced from the Samira Hill Gold
Mine, in Tera Department. The Samira Hill Gold Mine thus became the first
commercial gold production in the country. The reserves at the location were
estimated at 10,073,626 tons at an average grade of 2.21 grams (0.078 oz) per
ton from which 19,200 kilograms (42,300 lb) will be recovered over a six-year
mine life. Other gold deposits are believed to be in nearby areas known as the
"Samira Horizon", which is located between Gotheye and Ouallam.

SONICHAR (Société Nigerienne de Charbon) in Tchirozerine (north of Agadez)
extracts coal from an open pit and fuels an electricity generating plant that
supplies energy to the uranium mines. Based on 2012 reports by the government
of Niger, 246016 tons of coal were extracted by SONICHAR in 2011. There are
additional coal deposits to the south and west that are of a higher quality
and may be exploitable. Substantial deposits of phosphates, coal, iron,
limestone, and gypsum have also been found in Niger.
openai_summarised_points: • The mining industry in Niger constitutes the primary source of national exports, with uranium being the largest export commodity.
• Niger has been exporting uranium since the 1960s, experiencing significant export earnings and rapid economic growth during the 1960s and 1970s.
• Despite a persistent slump in uranium prices, the uranium sector continues to provide 72% of Niger's national export proceeds.
• The uranium-led economic boom ended in the early 1980s, leading to economic stagnation and limited new investment in the sector thereafter.
• Niger’s two uranium mines are SOMAIR, an open pit mine, and COMINAK, an underground mine; both are owned by a French-led consortium and operated by the French company Orano.
• By 2007, many mining licenses were sold to companies from India, China, Canada, and Australia to exploit new mineral deposits in Niger.

• In 2013, the Nigerien government sought to increase uranium revenues by applying the 2006 Mining Law to the two uranium mining companies, aiming to balance what it considered an unfavorable partnership with Areva (now Orano).
• Areva resisted the application of the 2006 Mining Law, citing concerns about the financial health of the companies due to declining uranium prices and unfavorable market conditions.
• After nearly a year of negotiations, in 2014 Areva agreed to the application of the 2006 Mining Law, which increased the government’s uranium revenue share from 5% to 12% (update needed).
• Beyond uranium, Niger has exploitable gold deposits located between the Niger River and the Burkina Faso border.
• In 2004, Niger produced its first gold ingot from the Samira Hill Gold Mine in Tera Department, marking the country’s first commercial gold production.

• The Samira Hill Gold Mine reserves were estimated at 10,073,626 tons with an average grade of 2.21 grams (0.078 oz) per ton, from which 19,200 kilograms (42,300 lb) of gold were expected to be recovered over a six-year mine life.
• Additional gold deposits are believed to exist in the "Samira Horizon" area, located between Gotheye and Ouallam.

• SONICHAR (Société Nigerienne de Charbon), located in Tchirozerine north of Agadez, extracts coal from an open pit mine and supplies fuel to an electricity generating plant that powers the uranium mines.
• According to 2012 government reports, SONICHAR extracted 246,016 tons of coal in 2011.
• Niger possesses additional coal deposits to the south and west of Tchirozerine, which are of higher quality and potentially exploitable.
• Substantial deposits of other minerals including phosphates, coal, iron, limestone, and gypsum have also been discovered in Niger.

text:
A test oil well in the Tenere Desert, January 2008

The history of oil prospecting and discovery goes back to the independence era
with the first discovery of the Tintouma oil field in Madama in 1975. The
Agadem basin in particular has attracted much attention since 1970 with Texaco
and then Esso prospecting in the basin until 1980. Exploration permits on the
same basin were held successively by Elf Aquitaine (1980–1985), Esso-Elf
(1985–1998), Esso (1998–2002), and Esso-Petronas (2002–2006). While the
reserves were estimated at 324 million barrels for oil and 10 billion m3 for
gas, Esso-Petronas relinquished the permit because it deemed the quantities
too small for production.

With the sudden increase in oil price by 2008, this assessment was no longer
true; consequently, the government transferred the Agadem block rights to
CNPC. Niger announced that in exchange for the US$5 billion investment, the
Chinese company would build wells, 11 of which would open by 2012, a
20,000-barrel-per-day (3,200 m3/d) SORAZ refinery near Zinder, and a pipeline
out of the nation. The government estimates the area has reserves of 324
million barrels (51,500,000 m3), and is seeking further oil in the Tenere
Desert and near Bilma. Niger began producing its first barrels of oil in 2011.
Government revenue from this is over $100 million per year, about 5% of
Niger's GDP, and slightly higher than from the uranium extraction industry.
openai_summarised_points: • The history of oil prospecting and discovery in Niger dates back to the independence era, with the first discovery of the Tintouma oil field in Madama in 1975.
• The Agadem basin has been a focal point for oil exploration since 1970, initially attracting companies such as Texaco and later Esso, which conducted prospecting activities until 1980.

• Exploration permits for the Agadem basin were successively held by several companies: Elf Aquitaine from 1980 to 1985, Esso-Elf from 1985 to 1998, Esso from 1998 to 2002, and Esso-Petronas from 2002 to 2006.

• The estimated reserves in the Agadem basin were 324 million barrels of oil and 10 billion cubic meters of gas; however, Esso-Petronas relinquished the permit in 2006, considering the quantities too small for commercial production at that time.

• By 2008, due to a sudden increase in global oil prices, the previous assessment of reserves being too small was reconsidered, prompting the Nigerien government to transfer the Agadem block rights to the China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC).

• Niger announced that CNPC would invest US$5 billion to develop the oil sector, including the construction of wells—11 of which were planned to open by 2012—a 20,000-barrel-per-day (3,200 m³/d) SORAZ refinery near the city of Zinder, and an export pipeline out of Niger.
• The Nigerien government estimates the Agadem basin reserves at 324 million barrels (51,500,000 m³) of oil and is actively seeking additional oil deposits in the Tenere Desert and near Bilma.
• Niger commenced its first commercial oil production in 2011, marking a significant milestone in its energy sector development.

• Government revenue from oil production exceeds $100 million annually, accounting for approximately 5% of Niger’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP), and this revenue surpasses that generated by the country’s uranium extraction industry.

text:
The economic competitiveness created by the January 1994 devaluation of the
Communauté Financière Africaine (CFA) franc contributed to an annual average
economic growth of 3.5% throughout the mid-1990s. But the economy stagnated
due to the sharp reduction in foreign aid in 1999 (which gradually resumed in
2000) and poor rains in 2000. Reflecting the importance of the agricultural
sector, the return of good rains was the primary factor underlying economic
growth of 5.1% in 2000, 3.1% in 2001, 6.0% in 2002, and 3.0% in 2003.

In recent years, the Government of Niger drafted revisions to the investment
code (1997 and 2000), petroleum code (1992), and mining code (1993), all with
attractive terms for investors. The present government actively seeks foreign
private investment and considers it key to restoring economic growth and
development. With the assistance of the United Nations Development Programme
(UNDP), it has undertaken a concerted effort to revitalize the private sector.

A market in Maradi.
openai_summarised_points: • The January 1994 devaluation of the Communauté Financière Africaine (CFA) franc enhanced Niger's economic competitiveness, resulting in an annual average economic growth rate of 3.5% throughout the mid-1990s.
• Economic stagnation occurred in 1999 due to a sharp reduction in foreign aid, which gradually resumed in 2000, coupled with poor rainfall in the year 2000.

• The agricultural sector's significance is underscored by the correlation between good rainfall and economic growth, with growth rates recorded at 5.1% in 2000, 3.1% in 2001, 6.0% in 2002, and 3.0% in 2003.

• The Government of Niger revised key legislative frameworks to attract investment, including the investment code (revised in 1997 and 2000), petroleum code (originally from 1992), and mining code (originally from 1993), all offering favorable terms for investors.
• The current government prioritizes foreign private investment as essential for restoring economic growth and development in Niger.
• With support from the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Niger has initiated a focused effort to revitalize its private sector.
• A market in Maradi exemplifies local economic activity, reflecting the importance of commerce in Niger’s economic landscape.

text:
In January 2000, Niger's newly elected government inherited serious financial
and economic problems including a virtually empty treasury, past-due salaries
(11 months of unpaid salaries) and scholarship payments, increased debt,
reduced revenue performance, and lower public investment. In December 2000,
Niger qualified for enhanced debt relief under the International Monetary Fund
program for Highly Indebted Poor Countries and concluded an agreement with the
Fund on a Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF).

In addition to changes in the budgetary process and public finances, the new
government has pursued economic restructuring towards the IMF promoted
privatization model. This has included the privatization of water distribution
and telecommunications and the removal of price protections for petroleum
products, allowing prices to be set by world market prices. Further
privatizations of public enterprises are in the works.

In its effort to comply with the IMF's Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility
plan, the government is also taking action to reduce corruption and, as the
result of a participatory process encompassing civil society, has devised a
Poverty Reduction Strategy Plan that focuses on improving health, primary
education, rural infrastructure, and judicial restructuring.

A long planned privatization of the Nigerien power company, NIGELEC, failed in
2001 and again in 2003 due to a lack of buyers. SONITEL, the nation's
telephone operator which was separated from the post office and privatised in
2001, was renationalised in 2009. Critics have argued that the obligations to
creditor institutions and governments have locked Niger into a process of
trade liberalization that is harmful for small farmers and in particular,
rural women.
openai_summarised_points: • In January 2000, Niger's newly elected government inherited severe financial and economic challenges, including a virtually empty treasury, 11 months of unpaid salaries and scholarship payments, increased national debt, reduced revenue performance, and decreased public investment.

• In December 2000, Niger qualified for enhanced debt relief under the International Monetary Fund (IMF) program for Highly Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) and finalized an agreement with the IMF on a Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF).
• The new government implemented changes in the budgetary process and public finances while pursuing economic restructuring aligned with the IMF-promoted privatization model.

• Privatization efforts included the sale of water distribution and telecommunications services, alongside the removal of price protections for petroleum products, allowing prices to be determined by world market rates.
• Additional privatizations of public enterprises were planned as part of ongoing economic reforms.

• To comply with the IMF's PRGF plan, the government initiated measures to reduce corruption and, through a participatory process involving civil society, developed a Poverty Reduction Strategy Plan focusing on improving health services, primary education, rural infrastructure, and judicial restructuring.
• The planned privatization of Niger's power company, NIGELEC, failed twice—in 2001 and again in 2003—due to a lack of interested buyers.
• SONITEL, the national telephone operator separated from the post office and privatized in 2001, was renationalized in 2009.

• Critics have contended that Niger's obligations to creditor institutions and governments have compelled the country to pursue trade liberalization policies that negatively impact small farmers, particularly rural women.

text:
A rural mother tends to her malnourished infant at the Maradi MSF aid centre,
during the 2005–2006 Niger food crisis. While the Maradi Region is the
breadbasket of Niger, the 20th century saw three severe Sahel droughts which
brought dramatic food insecurity to even the most fertile regions of Niger.
openai_summarised_points: • During the 2005–2006 Niger food crisis, a rural mother was documented tending to her malnourished infant at the Maradi Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) aid centre, highlighting the severe humanitarian impact of the crisis.
• The Maradi Region, recognized as the breadbasket of Niger due to its agricultural productivity, experienced significant food insecurity despite its fertile lands.

• Throughout the 20th century, Niger, including the Maradi Region, suffered from three severe Sahel droughts, which caused widespread food shortages and undermined the region's agricultural stability.
• These recurrent droughts in the Sahel zone led to dramatic food insecurity, affecting even the most agriculturally productive areas of Niger such as Maradi.

text:
One of the roads leading to Tahoua, central Niger View of Diori Hamani
International Airport at Niamey

Transport is crucial to the economy and culture of this vast landlocked
nation, with cities separated by huge uninhabited deserts, mountain ranges,
and other natural features. Niger's transport system was little developed
during the colonial period (1899–1960), relying upon animal transport, human
transport, and limited river transport in the far south west and south east.
No railways were constructed in the colonial period. Construction of a network
of paved roads linking major cities began after the independence reaching its
heights during the uranium boom in the 1970s and 1980s. Primary or paved road
systems are limited to bigger cities or connection between major cities. Road
connections or networks in rural areas are mostly unpaved, all-weather
laterite surfaces to grated dirt or sand plowed roads with various degrees of
maintenance. In 2012, there was 19,675 kilometres (12,225 mi) of road network
throughout Niger, of which 4,225 kilometres (2,625 mi) were paved.

The Niger River, which crosses the southwestern part of the country, is
unsuitable for river transport of any large scale, as it lacks depth for most
of the year, and is broken by rapids at many spots. Camel caravan transport
was historically important in the Sahara desert and Sahel regions which cover
most of the north.

Air transport is mainly concentrated in Niamey. Niger's only international
airport is Diori Hamani International Airport, is located in the capital,
Niamey. Other airports in Niger include the Mano Dayak International Airport
in Agadez city and Zinder Airport in Zinder city but as of January 2015, they
were not regularly serviced by any carriers.

In 2014, construction for the railway extension connecting Niamey (Niger) to
Cotonou via Parakou (Benin) began and was expected to be completed by 2016.
However, the project was still ongoing in 2018, and no recent reports have
been made as of 2022. It includes the construction of 574 kilometres (357 mi)
new railway from Niamey to connect to the existing line in Parakou (Benin).
Besides Niamey, the railway line will go through Dosso city and Gaya.
openai_summarised_points: • Niger is a vast landlocked nation where transport is crucial to its economy and culture due to cities being separated by large uninhabited deserts, mountain ranges, and other natural features.

• During the colonial period (1899–1960), Niger's transport system was minimally developed, relying primarily on animal transport, human transport, and limited river transport in the far southwest and southeast regions.
• No railways were constructed in Niger during the colonial period.
• After independence, construction of a network of paved roads linking major cities began, reaching its peak during the uranium boom of the 1970s and 1980s.
• Primary or paved road systems in Niger are limited mainly to bigger cities or connections between major cities.
• Road connections in rural areas are predominantly unpaved, consisting of all-weather laterite surfaces to graded dirt or sand-plowed roads, with varying degrees of maintenance.
• As of 2012, Niger had a total road network of 19,675 kilometres (12,225 miles), of which 4,225 kilometres (2,625 miles) were paved.

• The Niger River crosses the southwestern part of the country but is unsuitable for large-scale river transport due to insufficient depth for most of the year and the presence of rapids at many locations.
• Historically, camel caravan transport was significant in the Sahara desert and Sahel regions, which cover most of northern Niger.
• Air transport in Niger is mainly concentrated in the capital city, Niamey.
• Niger's only international airport is Diori Hamani International Airport, located in Niamey.

• Other airports in Niger include Mano Dayak International Airport in Agadez city and Zinder Airport in Zinder city; however, as of January 2015, these airports were not regularly serviced by any carriers.
• In 2014, construction began on a railway extension project to connect Niamey, Niger, to Cotonou, Benin, via Parakou, Benin, with an expected completion date of 2016.
• By 2018, the railway extension project was still ongoing, and no recent progress reports had been made as of 2022.
• The railway extension involves constructing 574 kilometres (357 miles) of new track from Niamey to connect with the existing railway line in Parakou, Benin.
• The planned railway route from Niamey will pass through Dosso city and Gaya before linking to Parakou.

text:
Niger has insufficient access to the energy it needs. The country's energy
consumption is considered one of the lowest in the world. Niger's existing
systems of energy consumption are also very underdeveloped to sustain energy
efficiency within the state. Electricity access between urban areas such as
Niamey enable 50 percent electricity service, and rural areas with 20 to 40
percent electricity service, with the lowest region at 10 percent. Other
demands for electricity are met by NIGELEC, providing diesel generators and
thermal coal plants to create fuel for rent.
openai_summarised_points: • Niger experiences insufficient access to the energy it requires, with its overall energy consumption ranked among the lowest globally.
• The country's current energy consumption systems are significantly underdeveloped, resulting in low energy efficiency across the nation.
• Electricity access in urban areas such as Niamey reaches approximately 50 percent, indicating that half the urban population has electricity service.
• In rural regions, electricity access ranges between 20 to 40 percent, with some areas experiencing access as low as 10 percent, representing the lowest regional electricity coverage in Niger.

• To meet additional electricity demands, NIGELEC, the national electricity company, operates diesel generators and thermal coal plants to produce fuel for rent, supplementing the limited electricity infrastructure.

text:
Niger has three major energy consumption outlets; oil products, biofuel and
waste, and electricity. As of 2016, Niger's energy consumption includes 486
ktoe via oil products, 2,217 ktoe via biofuel and waste, and 84 ktoe via
electricity. Niger's predominant sources of energy are wood and charcoal, also
known as biomass. Out of the 2,747 ktoe of energy supply in the country, 70%
is from biomass. Households use up to 90% biomass due to the unavailability of
alternative sources, and the increased rates of imported energy that some
cannot afford. The most used oil products are liquefied petroleum gas, motor
gasoline, gas and diesel, other kerosene, and fuel oil.

A chart representing the total final consumption of Niger's energy sources.
openai_summarised_points: • Niger's energy consumption is primarily divided into three major outlets: oil products, biofuel and waste, and electricity.
• As of 2016, Niger's energy consumption amounted to 486 kilotonnes of oil equivalent (ktoe) from oil products.
• In the same year, biofuel and waste contributed 2,217 ktoe to Niger's total energy consumption.
• Electricity consumption in Niger was recorded at 84 ktoe in 2016.
• The predominant sources of energy in Niger are wood and charcoal, collectively referred to as biomass.
• Biomass accounts for 70% of the total 2,747 ktoe energy supply in Niger.
• Household energy consumption relies heavily on biomass, with up to 90% usage due to the lack of alternative energy sources.
• The high reliance on biomass in households is also driven by the increased cost of imported energy, making alternatives unaffordable for many.
• The most commonly used oil products in Niger include liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), motor gasoline, gas and diesel, other kerosene, and fuel oil.
• A chart (not included here) visually represents the total final consumption of Niger's various energy sources, highlighting the dominance of biomass.

Niger also gets partial access to hydroelectric power from dams created
alongside the Niger River.[_unreliable source?_] Hydroelectric power
contributes about 280 megawatts (MW) to Niger's energy collectively from
several hydropower sources, including 130 MW from the Kandadji, 122.5 from
River Niger in Gambou, and 26 MW from Dyondyonga in Mekrou. Getting renewable
energy via hydropower has proven controversial, due to the importance of
rainfall in acquiring energy. Again, these hydroelectric power dams are
creating energy for Niger via Nigeria.

Solar energy has also been used to provide energy access. From 2004 to 2010
solar power generation was implemented, but there was a significant drop from
2010 to 2012. However, since 2016 approximately 5 Gwh of solar power have been
used.

Niger has the potential to provide sustainable and renewable energy access
within the country, which would help increase its energy intake and cope with
the growing demands of the population. Several projects have been discussed to
make use of clean energy sources such as solar power, hydropower, grid power,
and wind power.

Many NGOs are working on funding projects to provide sustainable and renewable
energy in parts of Africa. Affording the resources to create sustainable
energy is one of the biggest barrier Niger faces, but agencies such as
International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) and AbuDhabi Fund for
Development (ADFD) are funding low developing countries, including Niger, to
help develop local renewable projects. Theses agencies will support projects
including a hybrid micro-grid project employing solar PV and advanced lithium-
ion batteries, a hydropower project, integrated wind and solar, and a
combination project consisting of micro-grid and solar home kits. In addition,
Lighting Africa, an NGO primarily working in Niger, is assisting in
sustainable energy development through two World Bank-sponsored Energy Access
Projects: the Niger Solar Electricity Project (NESAP), and the Regional Off-
Grid Electrification Project (ROGEP). These projects will work with grid
systems in two piloting countries, and this includes Niger. They will aim to
increase electricity access in households, businesses, and communities through
modern off-grid electrification.
openai_summarised_points: • Niger receives partial access to hydroelectric power generated from dams constructed along the Niger River, contributing approximately 280 megawatts (MW) collectively from multiple hydropower sources.
• The specific hydropower contributions include 130 MW from the Kandadji dam, 122.5 MW from the River Niger dam in Gambou, and 26 MW from the Dyondyonga dam in Mekrou.
• The acquisition of renewable energy via hydropower in Niger is controversial due to the reliance on rainfall, which affects energy generation stability and output.
• The hydroelectric power dams supplying Niger’s energy are primarily creating energy through infrastructure located in Nigeria.

• Solar energy has been utilized to improve energy access in Niger, with solar power generation implemented between 2004 and 2010, followed by a significant decline in solar energy use from 2010 to 2012.
• Since 2016, Niger has used approximately 5 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of solar power, indicating a resurgence in solar energy utilization.

• Niger possesses significant potential to expand sustainable and renewable energy access domestically, which would enhance its overall energy intake and address the increasing energy demands of its growing population.

• Various projects have been proposed or discussed in Niger to harness clean energy sources, including solar power, hydropower, grid power, and wind power, aiming to diversify and increase sustainable energy supply.
• Numerous non-governmental organizations (NGOs) are actively funding and supporting sustainable and renewable energy projects across Africa, including Niger.
• A major barrier to sustainable energy development in Niger is the affordability and availability of financial resources required to establish renewable energy infrastructure.

• International agencies such as the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) and the Abu Dhabi Fund for Development (ADFD) provide funding to low developing countries, including Niger, to support the development of local renewable energy projects.

• Funded projects supported by these agencies in Niger include a hybrid micro-grid project utilizing solar photovoltaic (PV) technology combined with advanced lithium-ion batteries, a hydropower project, integrated wind and solar power systems, and a combined micro-grid and solar home kits initiative.
